@Elphyd This would increase the risk of students not being able to travel home in time for Christmas Day.

@Elphyd We are recommending students travel between 3 and 9 December because anyone who remains at university after 9 December and contracts coronavirus (COVID-19) or is contacted by NHS Test and Trace will have to isolate for up to 14 days at their term-time address. [3/4]

@KatieHullPR Hi Katie, Following the end of term break, our top priority for January will be the welfare of students, staff and the communities around Higher Education providers. [1/2]
@psymonbee [3/3] Students who exhibit symptoms but are not identified as a contact will be allowed to travel home by any mode of transport and will not have to complete any periods of self-isolation.

@psymonbee [2/3] Students who are identified as a contact of someone who tested positive for COVID-19 are permitted to complete their self-isolation period of 14 days at home, travelling home via private transport wherever possible.

@psymonbee Hi Simon, only students who test positive for COVID-19 will be required by law to self-isolate at their university accommodation before travelling home at the end-of-term.  They will need to self-isolate for a period of 10 days before travelling home. [1/3]

@AngusJWilkinson Hi Angus, following the end of the period of national restrictions on 2 December, research students will be able to continue in-person research activities if the research cannot reasonably be conducted from home. [1/5]

This is @StarAcademies advice for handling confirmed cases of COVID-19 in schools. You can read the full blog by @MuftiPatel here üëá
https://t.co/8ZRr8GvRkn

7. Prepare to respond

If a pupil or staff develops symptoms, have your response ready. Analyse seating plans, talk to the symptomatic person to help identify their close contacts, create scripts to notify the LA, DfE & parents of cases & actions. This will all build confidence.

6. Involve parents

Being a parent during the COVID-19 outbreak is hard. Parents are your school‚Äôs partners in protecting the school community against COVID-19. Keeping them informed and sharing information about minimising contact & responding to symptoms can be very helpful.

5. Monitor, adjust, repeat

By monitoring movement around school, leaders can identify hot spots, notice pupils (& staff) who need encouragement & make tweaks to the routine. Checking the system & processes can build a sense of affirmation for leaders & help alleviate stress.

4. Control breaks and lunchtimes

Encourage pupils to interact with consistent small groups & to keep their distance. Ask them to note who they socialise with in their planner to aid contact tracing. Staggered breaks & lunchtimes outside with designated areas will minimise risk.

3. Maintain accurate, non-negotiable seating plans

All pupils sit facing the front in allocated places that are as consistent as possible if pupils are taught in different classes. Well-constructed seating plans enable swift track & trace in the case of a positive COVID-19 case.

2. Micro-manage corridor movement

Carefully plotting pupils‚Äô movement in corridors through communal spaces minimises the risk of cross-contamination. Think through where and when students move, and have a process in place ‚Äì forward-facing lines, empty corridors, staff escort.

1. Assigning bubbles to home bases

Limit pupil movement. For primary schools & KS3, pupils remain in consistent classes as far as possible. For older secondary pupils where subject choices make this difficult, we encourage them to take care over sanitising, distancing & hygiene.

Chief Executive of @StarAcademies, @MuftiPatel, shares the 7 key protective measures his schools have taken to avoid sending an entire year group home when an outbreak occurs, while ensuring all pupils and staff are safe.

This is @StarAcademies advice for handling confirmed cases of COVID-19 in schools. You can read the full blog by @MuftiPatel here üëá
https://t.co/8ZRr8GvRkn

7. Prepare to respond

If a pupil or staff develops symptoms, have your response ready. Analyse seating plans, talk to the symptomatic person to help identify their close contacts, create scripts to notify the LA, DfE & parents of cases & actions. This will all build confidence.

6. Involve parents

Being a parent during the COVID-19 outbreak is hard. Parents are your school‚Äôs partners in protecting the school community against COVID-19. Keeping them informed and sharing information about minimising contact & responding to symptoms can be very helpful.

5. Monitor, adjust, repeat

By monitoring movement around school, leaders can identify hot spots, notice pupils (& staff) who need encouragement & make tweaks to the routine. Checking the system & processes can build a sense of affirmation for leaders & help alleviate stress.

4. Control breaks and lunchtimes

Encourage pupils to interact with consistent small groups & to keep their distance. Ask them to note who they socialise with in their planner to aid contact tracing. Staggered breaks & lunchtimes outside with designated areas will minimise risk.

3. Maintain accurate, non-negotiable seating plans

All pupils sit facing the front in allocated places that are as consistent as possible if pupils are taught in different classes. Well-constructed seating plans enable swift track & trace in the case of a positive COVID-19 case

2. Micro-manage corridor movement

Carefully plotting pupils‚Äô movement in corridors through communal spaces minimises the risk of cross-contamination. Think through where and when students move, and have a process in place ‚Äì forward-facing lines, empty corridors, staff escort.

1. Assigning bubbles to home bases

Limit pupil movement. For primary schools & KS3, pupils remain in consistent classes as far as possible. For older secondary pupils where subject choices make this difficult, we encourage them to take care over sanitising, distancing & hygiene.

@busymoonlight Hi, yes childminders can call the advice service if they want support on how to respond to a positive case of coronavirus in their setting.

Our stats show that last week 99.9% of schools were open with 88% of pupils attending. Schools must only send home those people who have been in close contact with a person who has tested positive, and advise them to self-isolate for 14 days.

These are the symptoms you should be looking out for if you think your child may have #coronavirus.

Check the NHS website for advice: https://t.co/JD1KGa9CQU https://t.co/Afd9YBfbon
For more information on what happens in the event of a pupil showing coronavirus symptoms at school, read our blog https://t.co/ZHlm4djmlw. (5/5)
Schools must only send home those people who have been in close contact with the person who has tested positive, and advise them to self-isolate for 14 days. (4/5)
A team of advisers will inform education settings what action is needed in response to a positive case based on the latest public health advice, and work through a risk assessment. (3/5)

If a positive case is confirmed, swift action will be taken to ask those who have been in close contact with them to self-isolate. There is a new dedicated advice service to support schools, colleges and early years if they have a confirmed case. (2/5)

Pupils and staff should get tested if:
1. They develop one or more of the main coronavirus symptoms: a high temperature; a new, continuous cough; or the loss or change of their sense of taste or smell; or
2. They are recommended to get tested by a healthcare provider. 
(1/5)
